comment: I went to school with the family. They all had such energy then you would never have known what had happened

Sad but also beautiful story...
Thankyou for sharing your personal experiences. So sad for all your loss and how it affected u all individually. You all have a wonderful mom ..stay strong...
The kids are as bat shit crazy as the father! Hell! They all need help! Only the mother looks as If she's stable! They are screwed! The UK has free healthcare! They should sign the whole family!
Wow what a wonderful documentary. I just finished watching it. I love this family. May God be the father of this family.

Think all the kids act immature falling out like toddlers over mindless stuff and it's clear they are out of touch with reality.  Dad was mentally unwell. Feel sorry for the mum. Cringed at the kids all the way through to be honest.

need to raise awareness that everyone is going to experience this sometime in there life.  where it is lost of health, ability or loved ones. society need to change we are more connected to technology now then ever but disconnected from life. humans aren't designed to take on all the stress of modern life and rates of suicide amongst family men is a hidden pandemic.  families do need dads  i grew up missed that  its caused great grief no body teach or be by your side leads to generational depression

I believe it was something more than just clinically depressed here (having severe depression myself), but to mock a serious illness by saying "he had kids, he's a selfish pig", or whatever, is cruel. Something was seriously wrong, as w cancer, MS etc...we don't condemn them.

Yesterday I was thinking ''I need encouragement to keep going.'' This documentary really broke my heart. I cried under the whole documentary. I have suicidal thoughts, and this doc. really did that I was thinking of my own family. I realized that I can't let the demons win. I can't give up everything, even if I hate my life. I had my suicide planned out before this documentary. I still have suicidal thoughts, but I'm not going to die yet. Thank you for that. / 18/04/06

The family was bright and good looking, of that there is no doubt, but the stress of raising so many daughters must have been very affecting mentally.

I just finished this film. What a haunting, devastating, beautiful and hopeful film this was, and by the end, I was completely in love with this family. This would be my choice for the best film of 2017!

Excellent documentary.

Considering his original plan was to kill the entire family, I'd say he did everyone a favor.  Mom is in desperate need of help and support, I admire her greatly for getting through each day and keeping the kids together, but the yard and house are in desperate need of cleaning up and organization.  Good film and I hope each one of them gets the help they need to be able to push forward in life and to help mom out with the house, at some point.
this doc broke my heart
I would love to be able to listen to the music of Paul Shanks. Is there a sound track to this film?

Loved the documentary, but hate this trailer! "Grief becomes strength"? That's clearly not what the filmmaker is saying at all! The tooth-aching sugar-coating in the trailer really demeans a poignant and beautifully made film. It's dark, dramatic and fascinating - doesn't need to be made palatable.

Calling someone who is clinically depressed and commits suicide "selfish" is tantamount to calling someone who is gay "perverted".
Only some people here will get why this is wrong. The others (mainly the religious folk) will be like "duh!"
This just brought tears to my eyes. My best friend killed herself in April, I can't relate
Looks like an interesting story, but there's a worrying lack of diversity in the casting. Not good enough, Netflix.

This should hopefully makeup for the mockery and excuse for suicide awareness that was '13 Reasons Why', which was basically a YA-rendition of a very serious and currently taboo subject.

This looks like the type of content people should be viewing, if they really want to understand and 'feel' the importance of mental health, and the absolute sense of hopelessness you can feel, despite having the best things in the world. Which, obviously in this man's case, was his daughters.

This documentary looks incredibly profound.
This hits close to home. When I was in high school my uncle committed suicide and left his wife and eight children. Powerful and sad.

Know your limitations. I have one kid and I'm stopping at one. I want to maximize my love and resources on to one hopefully productive member of society. There is way less at stake this way. My Fathers family had nine children and raised them in poverty. They aren't well adjusted. My mothers family had 14 rich little assholes, also not very well adjusted. I myself am the youngest of three. We were poor but we turned out ok. I know my limitations emotionally and fiscally, one kid is enough.
